text:
The best solution I’ve found to this still isn’t perfect honestly. It basically involves making a G Sheet which tracks each piece of content and the features/product areas it features. That way when we get a message from a client that one of these features has been updated/extended or a related feature has been introduced, we know which ~ 20-30 posts need to be updated within the next 1-2 weeks. It doesn’t fix the labor required to update them but when you know definitively how many need to be updated it’s a bit easier because (1) there’s an end in sight and (2) you don’t have to go looking for every single page.

The G Sheet takes a while to get right depending on the nuance of the software itself of course / how you announce features.

This is an excellent question though - I wonder how others handle it :)

text: Hi, we are quite focused on video content . But since we don't have a big budget, we focus on creating video content which: 1) A blog article that had high traffic from organic and a *keyword that is ranked contains a video pack* in the top 3 results (we then process the blog into a video and attach it to the blog) 2) when the video has good reach on social networks for the competition (according to buzzsumo) we managed to replicate multiple times video content (Quite successfully).  3)Focus on "Youtube SEO" see <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NY3y0V9UDwM> . There are not many topics that we process and are relevant to us in this way, but thanks to the fact that we focus on what works organically for google, youtube or social networks, we can achieve a high reach even without paying.

attachments.title: YouTube SEO: How to Rank Your Videos #1
attachments.fallback: YouTube Video: YouTube SEO: How to Rank Your Videos #1

text:
Hi everyone! Kind of the 11th hour but I’m hitting a wall and figured I’d ask the amazing audience: does your blog home page HAVE to be paginated for good SEO? Or can you have kind of a fake ‘vanity’ home page that just features specific content you want to curate? Would it be weird to have that page lead into a more traditional paginated layout?

*I think the user experience is more intuitive without antiquated pagination and just specific curated content, but I’m afraid we’re missing out on SEO if we don’t have it.*

Many thanks!

elements.text: Hi everyone! Kind of the 11th hour but I’m hitting a wall and figured I’d ask the amazing audience: does your blog home page HAVE to be paginated for good SEO? Or can you have kind of a fake ‘vanity’ home page that just features specific content you want to curate? Would it be weird to have that page lead into a more traditional paginated layout?
I think the user experience is more intuitive without antiquated pagination and just specific curated content, but I’m afraid we’re missing out on SEO if we don’t have it.
Many thanks!

text: <@UV5GVN7M2> as long as you ensure your linking to new content is solid, you can design it however you'd like -- one example I've worked on personally is the resource center for Grasshopper --> <https://grasshopper.com/resources/> we didn't go pagination and opted for guiding people to the resources best suited for their needs

text: I think the biggest thing that we want to make sure is that we don't "orphan" (gosh, I don't love that term) pages as we continue to build out the website. Having solid, crawlable pagination is one of the best ways to make sure that even after a long time publishing content, everything can still get crawled regularly when you make updates.

elements.text: I think the biggest thing that we want to make sure is that we don't "orphan" (gosh, I don't love that term) pages as we continue to build out the website. Having solid, crawlable pagination is one of the best ways to make sure that even after a long time publishing content, everything can still get crawled regularly when you make updates.

text: I've got 10 years of B2B tech experience - half in PR agencies and half in freelance in-house marketing roles. You name a type of technology, I've written about it. So, I'm not an expert in any one area (guess I'm more of a generalist) but I'm a solid writer. My last full-time contract role ended in August 2019 and I've had a few freelance gigs since then. Are there any niche skills I can acquire to improve my chances of landing a full-time non-contract role?

elements.text: I've got 10 years of B2B tech experience - half in PR agencies and half in freelance in-house marketing roles. You name a type of technology, I've written about it. So, I'm not an expert in any one area (guess I'm more of a generalist) but I'm a solid writer. My last full-time contract role ended in August 2019 and I've had a few freelance gigs since then. Are there any niche skills I can acquire to improve my chances of landing a full-time non-contract role?

text: <@U0177RLHFC2> re: disavows

elements.text: re: disavows

text:
I think learning about the nuances of inbound marketing goes a long way into landing a role (that's how I landed all my FT roles previously). 

Take a look at Hubspot's Inbound Marketing & Inbound courses; they cover the basic tenets very well and can set you off on the right path.

And once you've done that, pick a niche. For me, it's B2B SaaS. You can pick any.

elements.text:

text: i love this question. i don’t have great data to back this up but i think a blog home page should essentially be a table of contents. if someone lands there, it means they aren’t really sure where else to go. give them a few options where they can dive into something else deeper. a blog home page should have a super low bounce rate bc so many people are clicking through. pagination mostly stinks and don’t even get me started on infinite scroll!!!

text: I love this idea from Tomasz Tunguz <https://tomtunguz.com/secret-productive-group-meetings-video/>

attachments.title: The Secret to Productive Group Meetings over Video by @ttunguz
attachments.text: In 2017, I wrote the post Managers Must be Insane to Brainstorm in Groups. If you’ve been a group meeting for brainstorming, you’ll identify with the three problems reasearchers identified with in-person brainstorms: Only one person can speak at a time. Many people don’t participate and free ride hiding in the back of the room, unengaged. Some attendees are glossophobes: they fear speaking in public. And you’ll resonate with the frustration of this meeting format.
attachments.fallback: Tomasz Tunguz: The Secret to Productive Group Meetings over Video by @ttunguz

elements.text: I love this idea from Tomasz Tunguz

text:
I'm F/T in-house, but i've received a lot of freelance pitches. I'd say any industry adjacent to what you're doing now or have done in the past is a good fit.

Example: If you've done accounting software, maybe you can write more about financial tools or business management software?  And then I'd  look for those

text:
Hi. Someone reached out to me this morning, asking for recommendations for tools to schedule/manage social media. I am curious to learn if anyone in this group has recommendations beyond Buffer and Hootsuite.

Thanks so much for your thoughts.

elements.text:
Hi. Someone reached out to me this morning, asking for recommendations for tools to schedule/manage social media. I am curious to learn if anyone in this group has recommendations beyond Buffer and Hootsuite.

Thanks so much for your thoughts.

text: I use SproutSocial. Great for scheduling. Less great for actually monitoring and engaging in real time.

elements.text: I use SproutSocial. Great for scheduling. Less great for actually monitoring and engaging in real time.

text: We use Sprout Social as well

elements.text: We use Sprout Social as well

text: It allows you to engage with people who engage with you directly, but I’ve definitely done a lot less spontaneous engagement (especially on Twitter) since switching to it from Hootsuite.

elements.text: It allows you to engage with people who engage with you directly, but I’ve definitely done a lot less spontaneous engagement (especially on Twitter) since switching to it from Hootsuite.

text: Mostly Buffer for social media, but just started exploring Publer as an option too.

elements.text: Mostly Buffer for social media, but just started exploring Publer as an option too.

text: I used Social Pilot during my time in an agency. It's great, except the fact that Instagram needs to be posted manually (you get a notifications, with the photo downloaded automatically and copy already copied to your phone).

text:
Any hub-spoke-topic cluster-experts out there...?

Got a meta question for you: Can you have a really awesome topic cluster w/o a pillar page? Like everything is really well linked internally & silo'd together but there's no central page?

The reason I'm asking: I feel like a pillar page would compete/cannibalize our top converting "money" page (i love the phrase "money page") but that supporting topic pages would still be helpful
